title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Exploratory time series analysis


Seasons and calendrical patterns


29th June 2025 @ ISF 2025

Mitchell O‚ÄôHara-Wild, Nectric







Useful links


 social.mitchelloharawild.com
 workshop.nectric.com.au/isf2025/
 mitchelloharawild/workshop-etsa-isf2025

title: Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising temporal patterns
Creating a time plot with autoplot() is quick and easy. A time plot can also be made with ggplot2‚Äôs grammar for more options.

pbs_scripts |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = Month, y = Scripts)) +
  geom_line()

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising temporal patterns
The time plot allows us identify the presence of seasonality, but it is less effective in seeing the shape of seasonal patterns.







Question


How else could we represent time to more clearly show annual seasonal patterns?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality
Adjusting the plot‚Äôs x-axis so that it shows cyclical time (month of year) rather than continuous time (year month) highlights seasonal patterns.






Your turn


Try adjusting the following code to plot month of year along the x-axis.

pbs_scripts |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = Month, y = Scripts)) +
  geom_line()

Hint: lubridate::month() and lubridate::year() are useful tools for extracting the month and year from time.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality

pbs_scripts |> 
  ggplot(aes(
    x = month(Month, label = TRUE),
    y = Scripts, group = year(Month)
  )) +
  geom_line() + 
  labs("Month of Year")

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality















Your turn


Describe the shape of the seasonal pattern.
When are the most scripts (the peak) and the least scripts (the trough) issued?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
The season plot

pbs_scripts |> 
  gg_season(Scripts, period = "1 year")








This plot is known as a season plot, which can be made quickly with the plot helper function gg_season().

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
The seasonal period

pbs_scripts |> 
  gg_season(Scripts, period = "1 year")

The period argument is a duration for the length of the data‚Äôs seasonal pattern.
It works by rescaling the x-axis so that it repeats after each year.
Other common seasonal periods include:

1 week
1 day
1 hour

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality

The aus_production dataset contains the production of Australian Gas in petajoules (among other goods).


aus_production |> 
  autoplot(Gas)















Your turn


Plot the shape of the seasonal pattern, in which quarter does Australia produce the most and least gas?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality

aus_production |> 
  gg_season(Gas, period = "1 year")















Describing the seasonal pattern


This plot shows that peak production is in Q3 with a trough in Q1. Seasonality is getting stronger recently.











Can we do better?


It‚Äôs hard to see the seasonality from the early data, how can we improve it?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality


aus_production |> 
  gg_season(log(Gas), period = "1 year")











aus_production |> 
  gg_season(Gas, period = "1 year") + 
  scale_y_log10()















Plotting log transformed data


Recall that log transforming the data rescales multiplicative patterns into additive ones.












Can we do better?


The trend makes it difficult to compare across and within seasons, can we remove the trend?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality







Remap the aesthetics


Swap the x and colour aesthetic mappings to plot the years on the x-axis, with colours for each quarter.






Code
aus_production |> 
  model(STL(log(Gas))) |> 
  components() |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = year(Quarter), y = season_year, 
             colour = paste0("Q", quarter(Quarter)))) + 
  geom_line() + 
  labs(x = "Time", y = "Seasonality", colour = "Quarter", title = "Gas production in Australia")
















Gas production in Q1 is increasing while Q3 is decreasing.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality







Remap the aesthetics


Swap the x and colour aesthetic mappings to plot the years on the x-axis, with colours for each quarter.






Code
aus_production |> 
  model(STL(log(Gas))) |> 
  components() |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = year(Quarter), y = season_year, 
             colour = paste0("Q", quarter(Quarter)))) + 
  geom_line() + 
  labs(x = "Time", y = "Seasonality", colour = "Quarter", title = "Gas production in Australia")
















Gas production in Q1 is increasing while Q3 is decreasing.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising seasonality






Facet by season


This produces a ‚Äòseasonal sub-series plot‚Äô, which is useful for visualising changes in seasonality over time.





Code
aus_production |> 
  model(STL(log(Gas))) |> 
  components() |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = year(Quarter), y = season_year)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  facet_grid(cols = vars(paste0("Q", quarter(Quarter)))) +
  labs(x = "Time", y = "Seasonality", title = "Gas production in Australia")

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
The seasonal subseries plot

aus_production |> 
  gg_subseries(Gas, period = "1 year")








This plot is known as a seasonal subseries plot, which can be made quickly with the plot helper function gg_subseries().

title: Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Changing seasonality






Your turn!


Is the seasonal pattern in the total subsidised prescriptions (Scripts) in Australia changing over time?




pbs_scripts <- PBS |>
  summarise(Scripts = sum(Scripts))
pbs_scripts |>
  autoplot(Scripts)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Recap of plotting time series

Time plots
Season plots
Seasonal subseries plots

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Complex seasonality
Complex seasonality describes two or more seasonal patterns.
Complex seasonal patterns:

often interact with each-other
can be based on other calendars (e.g.¬†holidays)








Frequent seasonality


Multiple seasonality is common in daily & sub-daily data.
It can be difficult to forecast, so first consider if you need daily or sub-daily forecasts for making decisions.

text:
Victorian electricity demand

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Complex seasonality
There are two key strategies for clearly plotting multiple seasonal patterns:







Temporal aggregation


Aggregate time into coarser frequencies to sum over finer-grained seasonal patterns.
This is useful for plotting annual seasonality











Seasonal decomposition


Separate each of the seasonal patterns using MSTL (multiple seasonal trend by loess) decomposition.
This is best for daily / weekly seasonality

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Temporal aggregation
The Victorian electricity demand data has three seasonal patterns:

Annual (weather)
Weekly (work)
Daily (sleep)

The original data has a 30 minute frequency.

vic_elec

# A tsibble: 52,608 x 5 [30m] <Australia/Melbourne>
   Time                Demand Temperature Date       Holiday
   <dttm>               <dbl>       <dbl> <date>     <lgl>  
 1 2012-01-01 00:00:00  4383.        21.4 2012-01-01 TRUE   
 2 2012-01-01 00:30:00  4263.        21.0 2012-01-01 TRUE   
 3 2012-01-01 01:00:00  4049.        20.7 2012-01-01 TRUE   
 4 2012-01-01 01:30:00  3878.        20.6 2012-01-01 TRUE   
 5 2012-01-01 02:00:00  4036.        20.4 2012-01-01 TRUE   
 6 2012-01-01 02:30:00  3866.        20.2 2012-01-01 TRUE   
 7 2012-01-01 03:00:00  3694.        20.1 2012-01-01 TRUE   
 8 2012-01-01 03:30:00  3562.        19.6 2012-01-01 TRUE   
 9 2012-01-01 04:00:00  3433.        19.1 2012-01-01 TRUE   
10 2012-01-01 04:30:00  3359.        19.0 2012-01-01 TRUE   
# ‚Ñπ 52,598 more rows

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Temporal aggregation
When plotted at a 30 minute frequency, it is difficult to see any seasonal pattern clearly.

vic_elec |> 
  autoplot(Demand)

Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal decomposition
This is effective in combination with season plots to show seasonal patterns.

dcmp |> 
  gg_season(season_year, period = "1 year")

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal decomposition
This is effective in combination with season plots to show seasonal patterns.

dcmp |> 
  gg_season(season_week, period = "1 week")

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal decomposition
This is effective in combination with season plots to show seasonal patterns.

dcmp |> 
  gg_season(season_day, period = "1 day")

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal decomposition
Specific combinations of seasonal patterns can also be computed and plotted.


dcmp |> 
  gg_season(season_day + season_week, 
            period = "1 week")
















Caution: model limitations


Recall the STL decomposition is additive, so interactions between different seasonality will not be captured. The seasonal components are only as accurate as the model.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal decomposition

ped_dcmp |> 
  gg_season(season_week, period = "1 week")















Interaction effects


The weekly seasonal pattern interacts with the daily seasonal pattern, so the model doesn‚Äôt work here.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal decomposition

ped_dcmp |> 
  gg_season(season_day, period = "1 day")














Interaction effects


The weekly seasonal pattern interacts with the daily seasonal pattern, so the model doesn‚Äôt work here.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal decomposition






Interaction effects


Combine interacting seasonalities and use facets to separate the interactions (e.g.¬†weekday and weekend effects).





ped_dcmp |> 
  mutate(Weekday = wday(Date_Time, week_start = 1) %in% 1:5) |> 
  gg_season(season_day + season_week, period = "1 day") + 
  facet_wrap(vars(Weekday))

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Calendar plots
Using calendar layouts for time plots helps to visualise a large number of frequent (sub-daily) observations.
This is especially useful to show calendar specific patterns such as holidays.

library(sugrrants)
vic_elec |> 
  filter(Time < as.Date("2012-05-01")) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = hms::as_hms(Time), y = Demand)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  facet_calendar(~ Date, nrow = 2)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Calendar plots






Your turn!


Create a calendar plot for the first few months of pedestrians at Southern Cross Station.
Here‚Äôs some code to get you started.

pedestrian |> 
  filter(Sensor == "Southern Cross Station") |> 
  filter(Date_Time < as.Date(???)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = hms::as_hms(???), y = ???)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  facet_???(???)

Can you see any holiday effects?

title: Exercises
text:
The pedestrian dataset contains hourly pedestrian counts from 2015-01-01 to 2016-12-31 at 4 sensors in the city of Melbourne.
The data is shown below:


# A tibble: 66,037 √ó 5
   Sensor         Date_Time           Date        Time Count
   <chr>          <dttm>              <date>     <int> <int>
 1 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 00:00:00 2015-01-01     0  1630
 2 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 01:00:00 2015-01-01     1   826
 3 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 02:00:00 2015-01-01     2   567
 4 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 03:00:00 2015-01-01     3   264
 5 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 04:00:00 2015-01-01     4   139
 6 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 05:00:00 2015-01-01     5    77
 7 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 06:00:00 2015-01-01     6    44
 8 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 07:00:00 2015-01-01     7    56
 9 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 08:00:00 2015-01-01     8   113
10 Birrarung Marr 2015-01-01 09:00:00 2015-01-01     9   166
# ‚Ñπ 66,027 more rows








Your turn!



Identify the index variable, key variable(s), and measured variable(s) of this dataset.








Hint




The index variable contains the complete time information
The key variable(s) identify each time series
The measured variable(s) are what you want to explore/forecast.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Course Overview
Understanding how data changes over time is essential for specifying suitable forecasting models. Comprehensively exploring modern time-series datasets is challenging, where a large number of frequently observed time series contains many patterns. This workshop introduces new exploratory techniques to uncover meaningful temporal patterns in time series data.
We‚Äôll explore how to compare patterns across many series using feature-based summaries. Visualizing these features reveals common temporal patterns, cluster related time series, and see how these patterns vary throughout the hierarchical structure of the data.
We‚Äôll then use a grammar of time series graphics to produce plots that clearly show the shape and variability in these patterns. Special attention will be given to the complexities of sub-daily data (such as timezones), allowing us to create stunning calendar plots which uncovers holiday effects and complex seasonalities.
This practical workshop features live demonstrations and hands-on exercises using real-world data, equipping participants with the skills to effectively manipulate and visualize time series data in R.
This workshop will run in-person at ISF 2025 in Beijing, China on June 29th 2025.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Learning objectives
Participants will learn how to:

Use the tidyverse to wrangle and manipulate time series data
Visualize data and identify common time series patterns
Use time series features to find patterns in many time series
Apply the grammar of time series graphics to visualize complex seasonalities

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Instructor
 Mitchell O‚ÄôHara-Wild (he/him) is a PhD candidate at Monash University, creating new techniques and tools for forecasting large collections of time series with Rob Hyndman and George Athanasopoulos. He is the lead developer of the tidy time-series forecasting tools fable and feasts, and has co-developed the widely used forecast package since 2015. He is an award-winning educator, and has taught applied forecasting at Monash University and various forecasting workshops around the world.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Required equipment
Please bring your own laptop capable of running R.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Required software
To be able to complete the exercises of this workshop, please install a suitable IDE (such as RStudio), a recent version of R (4.1+) and the following packages.

Time series packages and extensions

fpp3
sugrrants


The following code will install the main packages needed for the workshop.
install.packages(c("fpp3", "sugrrants"))
Please have the required software installed and pre-work completed before attending the workshop.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
üéØ Today‚Äôs goals



Learn about tidy time series data.
Wrangle and summarise time series data.
Use temporal features to find patterns in many series.
Explore complex seasonalities and holiday patterns.








üåª Expectations



Follow the code of conduct.
Be kind and respectful.
Ask relevant questions any time, Q&A during breaks.
Make mistakes and learn!





https://workshop.nectric.com.au/isf2025/

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
üéì Active research


Some of the content in this workshop is active research.
We want to make time series data visualisation easier, and are creating new R packages and conceptual frameworks for visualising time with calendars.
Anonymous responses to polls, the end-of-class survey, and workshop discussions will be collected for research purposes.
You can find the explanatory statement for this research here: https://workshop.nectric.com.au/isf2025/ethics/explanatory-statement.pdf







üé• Recorded workshop


Audio and video from this workshop is being recorded.
The recording will be uploaded to YouTube and shared with you to review the materials. It will not be published publicly.
Anonymous transcribed excerpts may be used in our research.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Tidy time series analysis
This workshop is about tidy time series in R.

We‚Äôll be using these packages!

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Tidy time series packages
This workshop is about tidy time series in R.
Install them with:

# The tidy forecasting packages
install.packages("fpp3")

# Calendar visualisation layouts
install.packages("sugrrants")

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Tidy time series packages
# Data manipulation
library(dplyr)
# Plotting functions
library(ggplot2)
# Manipulate time
library(lubridate)
# Time series class
library(tsibble)
# Tidy time series datasets
library(tsibbledata)
# Feature extraction and statistics
library(feasts)
# Time series calendar graphics
library(sugrrants)


# All of the above
library(fpp3)
library(sugrrants)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Time series data

Four-yearly Olympic winning times
Annual Google profits
Quarterly Australian beer production
Monthly pharmaceutical subsidies
Weekly retail sales
Daily COVID-19 infections
Hourly electricity demand
Minutely blood glucose measurements
Time-stamped stock transaction data

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Time series data
Comes in all shapes and sizes!
Like all data, we hope it‚Äôs tidy üßπ







All time series data contain‚Ä¶



The time of the observation (index)
One or more observations (measurements)


Some datasets have identifying metadata,

Identifying variables for the series (key)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
The tsibble data format

A tsibble is a tibble for time series!
The quarterly visitors to Australia are found in the tourism dataset.

library(fpp3)
tourism

# A tsibble: 24,320 x 5 [1Q]
# Key:       Region, State, Purpose [304]
   Quarter Region   State           Purpose  Trips
     <qtr> <chr>    <chr>           <chr>    <dbl>
 1 1998 Q1 Adelaide South Australia Business  135.
 2 1998 Q2 Adelaide South Australia Business  110.
 3 1998 Q3 Adelaide South Australia Business  166.
 4 1998 Q4 Adelaide South Australia Business  127.
 5 1999 Q1 Adelaide South Australia Business  137.
 6 1999 Q2 Adelaide South Australia Business  200.
 7 1999 Q3 Adelaide South Australia Business  169.
 8 1999 Q4 Adelaide South Australia Business  134.
 9 2000 Q1 Adelaide South Australia Business  154.
10 2000 Q2 Adelaide South Australia Business  169.
# ‚Ñπ 24,310 more rows

Column types


In this dataset, the column types are:

index variable: Quarter
key variable(s): Region, State, and Purpose
measured variable(s): Trips

In this dataset, which columns are:

index variable(s)?
key variable(s)?
measured variable(s)?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Our first tsibble
A tsibble is a time series tibble.
It is created with as_tsibble().

tourism |> 
  as_tsibble(
    key = c(Region, State, Purpose),
    index = Quarter
  )

# A tsibble: 24,320 x 5 [1Q]
# Key:       Region, State, Purpose [304]
   Quarter Region   State           Purpose  Trips
     <qtr> <chr>    <chr>           <chr>    <dbl>
 1 1998 Q1 Adelaide South Australia Business  135.
 2 1998 Q2 Adelaide South Australia Business  110.
 3 1998 Q3 Adelaide South Australia Business  166.
 4 1998 Q4 Adelaide South Australia Business  127.
 5 1999 Q1 Adelaide South Australia Business  137.
 6 1999 Q2 Adelaide South Australia Business  200.
 7 1999 Q3 Adelaide South Australia Business  169.
 8 1999 Q4 Adelaide South Australia Business  134.
 9 2000 Q1 Adelaide South Australia Business  154.
10 2000 Q2 Adelaide South Australia Business  169.
# ‚Ñπ 24,310 more rows

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Our first tsibble






Exercise 2


Identify the index and key variables of the aus_accommodation dataset.
Then use as_tsibble() to convert it into a tsibble.

library(fpp3)
read.csv(
  "https://workshop.nectric.com.au/isf2025/data/aus_accommodation.csv"
)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Representing time indices

Time is surprisingly tricky to represent!

frequency
granularity
time zones
calendars
leap years (and seconds?!)
holidays
civil/absolute time
time periods

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Representing time indices

Common time points can be created with these functions:





Granularity
Function




Annual
start:end


Quarterly
yearquarter()


Monthly
yearmonth()


Weekly
yearweek()


Daily
as_date(), ymd()


Sub-daily
as_datetime()

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Creating a tsibble

Tidy the data into a long format
Appropriately class the time variable
Convert to tsibble with as_tibble(), identifying the index and key variable(s).







Follow along


Let‚Äôs convert the tourism dataset into a tsibble.

library(fpp3)
read.csv(
  "https://workshop.nectric.com.au/isf2025/data/tourism.csv"
)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Creating a tsibble

Tidy the data into a long format
Appropriately class the time variable
Convert to tsibble with as_tibble(), identifying the index and key variable(s).







Exercise 3


Redo the previous exercise, but this time use the appropriate time class for the index variable.
You should see the frequency of the tsibble matches the quarterly frequency of the measurements.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Manipulating time series data
Tidy time series data uses tidyverse tools!






Exercise 4


Try calculating the total tourists visiting Victoria from the tourism dataset.
Hint: use filter() to keep only visitors to ‚ÄúVictoria‚Äù, then summarise() to calculate the total trips.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Manipulating time series data
However there are some differences when working with time‚Ä¶
The time index is always preserved (implicit group_by()).






Grouping across time


Sometimes you want to summarise over time.
Summarising over all of time is no longer a time series, so first convert to a tibble with as_tibble().
To re-index by a new variable, use index_by().

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Visualising time series
Time series visualisation helps us identify time series patterns.
These patterns include:

trends
seasonalities
cycles
covariates
events

They also help identify anomalies/outliers.

:::

title: Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal or Cyclical?
These common patterns are commonly confused, can you tell them apart?






What‚Äôs the difference?


Seasonal patterns have‚Ä¶

Consistent and predictable shape,
Repeats with a fixed time period

Cyclical patterns have‚Ä¶

Inconsistent shape and amplitude,
Repeats with a variable time period

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal or Cyclical?
These common patterns are commonly confused, can you tell them apart?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal or Cyclical?
These common patterns are commonly confused, can you tell them apart?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal or Cyclical?
These common patterns are commonly confused, can you tell them apart?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal or Cyclical?
These common patterns are commonly confused, can you tell them apart?

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Time series decomposition
Decomposition separates time series patterns into individual series.






Additive decomposition via STL


\[y_t = S_t + T_t + R_t\]

\(y_t=\) data at time \(t\)
\(T_t=\) trend-cycle component at time \(t\)
\(S_t=\) seasonal component at time \(t\)
\(R_t=\) remainder component at time \(t\)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Additive & multiplicative patterns
STL only works with additive patterns
\[y_t = S_t + T_t + R_t\]


Code
library(ggplot2)

i <- 1:119
pattern_types_demo <- tsibble(
  time = yearmonth(i),
  season = sin(i*2*pi/12),
  trend = i,
  remainder = rnorm(length(i)),
  index = time
)
pattern_types_demo |> 
  tidyr::pivot_longer(c(season, trend, remainder)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = time, y = value, group = name)) +
  geom_line() +
  facet_grid(vars(name), scales = "free_y") + 
  labs(x = NULL, y = NULL)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Additive & multiplicative patterns
\[y_t = S_t + T_t + R_t\]


Code
pattern_types_demo |>
  autoplot(trend + 10*season + 3*remainder)

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Additive & multiplicative patterns
\[y_t = S_t \times T_t \times R_t\]


Code
pattern_types_demo |>
  autoplot((2 + season) * trend * (5 + remainder))

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Additive or multiplicative?
















Additive!


STL works for the patterns in this dataset.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Additive or multiplicative?
















Multiplicative!


STL won‚Äôt accurately decompose the patterns in this data.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
STL for multiplicative patterns
While STL doesn‚Äôt work directly with multiplicative patterns, we have a transformational trick ü™Ñ

\[\begin{align}
y_t &= S_t \times T_t \times R_t\\
\log(y_t) &= \log\left(S_t \times T_t \times R_t\right)\log\\
&= \log(S_t) + \log(T_t) + \log(R_t)
\end{align}\]








Other transformations


Multiplicative patterns aren‚Äôt always exactly multiplicative. Instead we often use power transformations via box_cox(y, lambda).
More info: https://otexts.com/fpp3/transformations.html

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
STL decomposition
Estimate STL decomposition with STL().

library(feasts)
dcmp <- tourism |> 
  summarise(Trips = sum(Trips)) |> 
  model(STL(Trips)) |> 
  components()
dcmp

# A dable: 80 x 7 [1Q]
# Key:     .model [1]
# :        Trips = trend + season_year + remainder
   .model     Quarter  Trips  trend season_year remainder season_adjust
   <chr>        <qtr>  <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl>     <dbl>         <dbl>
 1 STL(Trips) 1998 Q1 23182. 21378.       1243.     561.         21939.
 2 STL(Trips) 1998 Q2 20323. 21168.       -346.    -498.         20670.
 3 STL(Trips) 1998 Q3 19827. 20992.       -739.    -426.         20566.
 4 STL(Trips) 1998 Q4 20830. 20893.       -159.      96.7        20989.
 5 STL(Trips) 1999 Q1 22087. 21079.       1244.    -236.         20843.
 6 STL(Trips) 1999 Q2 21458. 21019.       -343.     782.         21801.
 7 STL(Trips) 1999 Q3 19914. 20893.       -737.    -241.         20652.
 8 STL(Trips) 1999 Q4 20028. 20712.       -168.    -516.         20196.
 9 STL(Trips) 2000 Q1 22339. 20599.       1247.     494.         21093.
10 STL(Trips) 2000 Q2 19941. 20791.       -339.    -512.         20280.
# ‚Ñπ 70 more rows

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
STL decomposition
Access decomposition with components().

library(feasts)
dcmp <- tourism |> 
  summarise(Trips = sum(Trips)) |> 
  model(STL(Trips)) |> 
  components()
dcmp

# A dable: 80 x 7 [1Q]
# Key:     .model [1]
# :        Trips = trend + season_year + remainder
   .model     Quarter  Trips  trend season_year remainder season_adjust
   <chr>        <qtr>  <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl>     <dbl>         <dbl>
 1 STL(Trips) 1998 Q1 23182. 21378.       1243.     561.         21939.
 2 STL(Trips) 1998 Q2 20323. 21168.       -346.    -498.         20670.
 3 STL(Trips) 1998 Q3 19827. 20992.       -739.    -426.         20566.
 4 STL(Trips) 1998 Q4 20830. 20893.       -159.      96.7        20989.
 5 STL(Trips) 1999 Q1 22087. 21079.       1244.    -236.         20843.
 6 STL(Trips) 1999 Q2 21458. 21019.       -343.     782.         21801.
 7 STL(Trips) 1999 Q3 19914. 20893.       -737.    -241.         20652.
 8 STL(Trips) 1999 Q4 20028. 20712.       -168.    -516.         20196.
 9 STL(Trips) 2000 Q1 22339. 20599.       1247.     494.         21093.
10 STL(Trips) 2000 Q2 19941. 20791.       -339.    -512.         20280.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
STL decomposition
Plot the decomposition with autoplot()

dcmp |> 
  autoplot()

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
STL decomposition
STL decomposition effectively separates trend and seasonality from the data.
This helps to more clearly see the underlying changes over time.






Fine-tuning decomposition


While the defaults usually work well, it‚Äôs worth learning how to adjust the decomposition for better results.
More info: https://otexts.com/fpp3/stl.html

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Seasonal adjustment
Seasonally adjusted data removes seasonal patterns to clearly see underlying trends.
Adjusted data is in the season_adjust column.

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Exploring many series
Most datasets contain many related time series identified by one or more keys.
For example, tourism contains 304 series.

tourism |> 
  distinct(Region, State, Purpose)

# A tibble: 304 √ó 3
   Region         State              Purpose 
   <chr>          <chr>              <chr>   
 1 Adelaide       South Australia    Business
 2 Adelaide       South Australia    Holiday 
 3 Adelaide       South Australia    Other   
 4 Adelaide       South Australia    Visiting
 5 Adelaide Hills South Australia    Business
 6 Adelaide Hills South Australia    Holiday 
 7 Adelaide Hills South Australia    Other   
 8 Adelaide Hills South Australia    Visiting
 9 Alice Springs  Northern Territory Business
10 Alice Springs  Northern Territory Holiday 
# ‚Ñπ 294 more rows

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Exploring many series
This can make visualising the patterns of each time series challenging.

tourism |> 
  autoplot() + 
  guides(colour = "none")

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Time series features
Instead we can calculate features of the time series, which summarise patterns over time.

tourism |> 
  features(Trips, feat_stl)

# A tibble: 304 √ó 12
   Region State Purpose trend_strength seasonal_strength_year seasonal_peak_year
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>            <dbl>                  <dbl>              <dbl>
 1 Adela‚Ä¶ Sout‚Ä¶ Busine‚Ä¶          0.464                  0.407                  3
 2 Adela‚Ä¶ Sout‚Ä¶ Holiday          0.554                  0.619                  1
 3 Adela‚Ä¶ Sout‚Ä¶ Other            0.746                  0.202                  2
 4 Adela‚Ä¶ Sout‚Ä¶ Visiti‚Ä¶          0.435                  0.452                  1
 5 Adela‚Ä¶ Sout‚Ä¶ Busine‚Ä¶          0.464                  0.179                  3
 6 Adela‚Ä¶ Sout‚Ä¶ Holiday          0.528                  0.296                  2
 7 Adela‚Ä¶ Sout‚Ä¶ Other            0.593                  0.404                  2
 8 Adela‚Ä¶ Sout‚Ä¶ Visiti‚Ä¶          0.488                  0.254                  0
 9 Alice‚Ä¶ Nort‚Ä¶ Busine‚Ä¶          0.534                  0.251                  0
10 Alice‚Ä¶ Nort‚Ä¶ Holiday          0.381                  0.832                  3
# ‚Ñπ 294 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 6 more variables: seasonal_trough_year <dbl>, spikiness <dbl>,
#   linearity <dbl>, curvature <dbl>, stl_e_acf1 <dbl>, stl_e_acf10 <dbl>

title: Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Time series features
STL decomposition based features include:






Seasonal strength (season_strength_year)


The signal to noise ratio of seasonality from 0-1.
\[\max\left(0, 1-\frac{\text{Var}(R_t)}{\text{Var}(S_t+R_t)}\right)\]









Trend strength (trend_strength)


The signal to noise ratio of trend from 0-1.
\[\max\left(0, 1-\frac{\text{Var}(R_t)}{\text{Var}(T_t+R_t)}\right)\]

title: Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
Exploratory time series analysis
text:
Many features for many series
There are many features beyond STL decomposition for describing time series patterns.

?features_by_tag
?features_by_pkg








More applications for features


Features can also be used for other tasks including clustering and anomaly detection.
More info: https://otexts.com/fpp3/features.html
